And the CDC </span><span><a href="https://apnews.com/article/coronavirus-pandemic-science-health-rochelle-walensky-centers-for-disease-control-and-prevention-fa39bf97bc5ad51df5163b2cb4f8c58d?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">shortened</a></span><span> the required isolation time for health workers who test positive to combat potential employee shortages during the Omicron wave.</span>

<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
SPACE
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/12/23/nasa-s-james-webb-space-telescope-finally-set-to-launch-on-christmas-day?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}&uid={{profile.vars.access_token}}">
<font color="#000000">
NASA’s Biggest Bet Since Astronaut Ice Cream
</font>
</a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/12/23/nasa-s-james-webb-space-telescope-finally-set-to-launch-on-christmas-day?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}&uid={{profile.vars.access_token}}" class="">
<img alt="James Webb Telescope in lab" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/dac7e80f9b2cabc743a944651a1e088d709c47db-985x644.jpg?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
</a><span class="source" style="display:inline-block;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px"><small><em><em>NASA/Desiree Stover</em></em></small></span>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">For the last 30(ish) years, scope-heads have eagerly anticipated the launch of NASA’s James Webb Space Telescope. And tomorrow, sometime around 7:20am ET, the largest and most powerful telescope to ever leave Earth <a href="https://www.nationalgeographic.com/science/article/at-long-last-the-james-webb-space-telescope-is-ready-to-launch?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">will begin</a> its million-mile journey into deep space from its launch site in French Guiana.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Its space plans:</strong> While its older brother Hubble mainly captured images in visible light, Webb was designed to take photos in infrared light. This means it can cut through space dust and gas to capture much older, never-before-seen stars and planets—and in doing so, could potentially see back to the beginning of the universe.<img src="https://emojipedia-us.s3.dualstack.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/thumbs/120/apple/237/shocked-face-with-exploding-head_1f92f.png" width="18" style="max-width:18px" alt=""></p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The specs: </strong>The telescope is three stories tall with a gold-plated mirror that stretches 21 feet wide. Its tennis court-sized sunshield will keep the telescope cozy at -370 degrees Fahrenheit, NPR reports.</p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">More delays than Spirit</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Although it was originally conceived as a $1–$3.5 billion project, the now $10 billion Webb telescope has suffered so many setbacks that some astronomers weren’t sure it would ever launch. NASA’s initial expected launch date was somewhere between 2007 and 2011, but in 2011 the House of Representatives voted to end the project. Bullish on the telescope’s potential to revolutionize astronomy, the scientific community rallied until the deep space dreams were brought back to life.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>There’s also been pushback around the telescope’s name. Critics pointed out that James Webb, the former NASA administrator that the telescope is named for, allowed government discrimination against gay and lesbian employees to take place while he was in charge.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>After NASA finished an internal investigation this year, it </span><span><a href="https://www.npr.org/2021/09/30/1041707730/shadowed-by-controversy-nasa-wont-rename-new-space-telescope?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">said</a></span><span> it had decided against changing the name.</span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Big picture:</strong> There’s a lot riding on the Webb telescope. <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/is-nasas-new-telescope-worth-the-risks/2021/12/23/d23984d0-6401-11ec-9b51-7131fa190c5e_story.html?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">One in every three dollars</a> spent on astrophysics at NASA in the last 20 years has gone to building this thing—and if something goes wrong (like, say, during its incredibly complicated <a href="https://www.businessinsider.com/nasa-james-webb-space-telescope-to-unfold-after-launch-2021-12?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">unfolding process</a>), the agency could have spent the last three decades building a multibillion-dollar pile of space debris.—<em>MM</em></p>
</div>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
GEOPOLITICS
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/12/23/biden-signs-bill-banning-imports-from-xinjiang-region-in-swipe-at-china?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}&uid={{profile.vars.access_token}}">
<font color="#000000">
Good Luck Finding 'Made in Xinjiang' Products
</font>
</a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/12/23/biden-signs-bill-banning-imports-from-xinjiang-region-in-swipe-at-china?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}&uid={{profile.vars.access_token}}" class="">
<img alt="Good Luck Finding 'Made in Xinjiang' Products" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/459dac765045d1ff729ae2f1978023cab6e636ad-1024x658.jpg?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
</a><span class="source" style="display:inline-block;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px"><small><em>VCG/VCG via Getty Images</em></small></span>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">It is <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2021/12/23/us-bans-imports-from-chinas-xinjiang-region-citing-uyghur-forced-labor.html?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">now illegal</a> to import goods from China’s Xinjiang region into the US unless companies can prove they weren’t made with forced labor, according to a historic bill signed by President Biden yesterday.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The law, which Congress passed with overwhelming bipartisan support, is the US government’s biggest move yet to punish China for its reported human rights abuses and genocide against mostly Muslim minorities in the region.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Big picture: </strong>While Xinjiang is a relatively obscure location in remote northwest China, it’s become a significant link in global supply chains, <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2021/12/23/us/politics/china-uyghurs-forced-labor.html?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">the NYT writes</a>. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Factories in Xinjiang produce electronics and apparel that are shipped all over the world.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>It also supplies an estimated 20% of the world’s cotton and nearly half of the world’s polysilicon—the raw material used to make solar panels.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line: </strong>US multinationals are stumbling as they try to balance Washington’s hostile stance toward China with trying to conduct business in the world’s second-largest economy. Want one example? Intel sparked huge backlash on Chinese social media after it told its suppliers to avoid sourcing goods from Xinjiang. The company <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/intel-apologizes-after-asking-suppliers-to-avoid-chinas-xinjiang-region-11640261303?mod=hp_lead_pos4" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">apologized</a> to its Chinese customers, partners, and the public yesterday.—<em>NF</em></p>
</div>

<tr>
<td style="padding-top: 12px;">

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
LABOR
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/organizing-just-got-easier-at-amazon-nlrb-settlement?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}&uid={{profile.vars.access_token}}">
<font color="#000000">
Organizing Just Got Easier at Amazon
</font>
</a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<a style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/organizing-just-got-easier-at-amazon-nlrb-settlement?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}&uid={{profile.vars.access_token}}" class="">
<img alt="Amazon fulfillment center " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/a949d1ad3296106255697a667a1f1326a89ce777-1024x683.jpg?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
</a><span class="source" style="display:inline-block;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px"><small><em>Matthew Horwood/Getty Images</em></small></span>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">An update to the ongoing tug-of-war between organized labor and Amazon: In <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2021/12/23/business/amazon-labor-deal.html?partner=slack&smid=sl-share" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">a nationwide settlement</a> with the National Labor Relations Board (NLRB), the company agreed to notify past and current employees—around 1 million people—about their rights to organize.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The settlement, finalized on Wednesday, also requires Amazon to end its “15-minute rule” that required employees to only be on company property within 15 minutes of the beginning or end of their shift (making organizing a major uphill battle).</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Given Amazon’s size—750,000+ people work in its US operations—the NLRB settlement is a massive shift in employees’ favor. And it comes amid a flurry of labor activity at Amazon in recent weeks:</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>The NLRB authorized a second union election at a warehouse in Alabama after finding that the company illegally interfered in the first vote.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Amazon warehouse workers in Staten Island refiled a request for a union vote.</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Amazon suspended its plan to ban cellphones in warehouses after six employees were killed when a tornado struck an Illinois facility. OSHA is investigating the tragedy.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Zoom out:</strong> Former NLRB chair Wilma B. Liebman said the settlement sends a signal to all large employers that the agency is serious about enforcing the law.—<em>MK</em></p>
</div>

</a>

<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
GRAB BAG
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/12/23/key-performance-indicators-december-24?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}&uid={{profile.vars.access_token}}">
<font color="#000000">
Key Performance Indicators
</font>

</h1>

<a style="text-decoration:none;border:none;" target="_blank" href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/12/23/key-performance-indicators-december-24?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew&mid={{md5(profile.email)}}&uid={{profile.vars.access_token}}" class="">
<img alt="A chart showing new home sales by price " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/6f931e96f89da7a1f0da561af57233933327e77c-1057x648.png?w=670&q=70&auto=format">
</a><span class="source" style="display:inline-block;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px"><small><em><a href="https://twitter.com/calculatedrisk">Calculated Risk</a></em></small></span>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<div>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Stat: </strong>Virtually <a href="https://twitter.com/calculatedrisk/status/1474071716846456839?s=20" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">no new homes</a> in the US sold for under $200,000 in November, according to a new report from the Commerce Department. Compare that to 2002, when houses priced under $200k accounted for 56% of all new home sales.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Quote:</strong> “In theory momentos serve to bring back the moment. In fact they serve only to make clear how inadequately I appreciated the moment when it was here.”</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Joan Didion, one of the greatest American writers of the past century, <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2021/12/23/books/joan-didion-dead.html?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">died yesterday</a> at 87. If you want to find out what made Didion such a profound cultural observer, start by checking out <a href="https://www.openculture.com/2014/01/read-17-joan-didion-essays-free-online-1966-to-2013.html?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">one of her essays</a> this weekend. Or devour one of <a href="https://byliner.com/joan-didion/stories/some-dreamers-of-the-golden-dream/?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">her many books</a>.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Read: </strong>How many people are legally named Santa Claus? (<a href="https://www.tampabay.com/life-culture/2021/12/21/who-are-americas-real-santa-clauses/?utm_campaign=mb&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_source=morning_brew" class="link" target="_blank" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Tampa Bay Times</a>)</p>
</div>

color=\"#000000\"\u003e\nNASA’s Biggest Bet Since Astronaut Ice Cream\n\u003c/font\u003e\n\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003ca style=\"text-decoration:none;border:none;\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2021/12/23/nasa-s-james-webb-space-telescope-finally-set-to-launch-on-christmas-day?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\u0026mid={{md5(profile.email)}}\u0026uid={{profile.vars.access_token}}\" class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"James Webb Telescope in lab\" style=\"display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/dac7e80f9b2cabc743a944651a1e088d709c47db-985x644.jpg?w=670\u0026q=70\u0026auto=format\"\u003e\n\u003c/a\u003e\u003cspan class=\"source\" style=\"display:inline-block;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px\"\u003e\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003cem\u003eNASA/Desiree Stover\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eFor the last 30(ish) years, scope-heads have eagerly anticipated the launch of NASA’s James Webb Space Telescope. And tomorrow, sometime around 7:20am ET, the largest and most powerful telescope to ever leave Earth \u003ca href=\"https://www.nationalgeographic.com/science/article/at-long-last-the-james-webb-space-telescope-is-ready-to-launch?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ewill begin\u003c/a\u003e its million-mile journey into deep space from its launch site in French Guiana.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eIts space plans:\u003c/strong\u003e While its older brother Hubble mainly captured images in visible light, Webb was designed to take photos in infrared light. This means it can cut through space dust and gas to capture much older, never-before-seen stars and planets—and in doing so, could potentially see back to the beginning of the universe.\u003cimg src=\"https://emojipedia-us.s3.dualstack.us-west-1.amazonaws.com/thumbs/120/apple/237/shocked-face-with-exploding-head_1f92f.png\" width=\"18\" style=\"max-width:18px\" alt=\"\"\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe specs: \u003c/strong\u003eThe telescope is three stories tall with a gold-plated mirror that stretches 21 feet wide. Its tennis court-sized sunshield will keep the telescope cozy at -370 degrees Fahrenheit, NPR reports.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eMore delays than Spirit\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAlthough it was originally conceived as a $1–$3.5 billion project, the now $10 billion Webb telescope has suffered so many setbacks that some astronomers weren’t sure it would ever launch. NASA’s initial expected launch date was somewhere between 2007 and 2011, but in 2011 the House of Representatives voted to end the project. Bullish on the telescope’s potential to revolutionize astronomy, the scientific community rallied until the deep space dreams were brought back to life.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThere’s also been pushback around the telescope’s name. Critics pointed out that James Webb, the former NASA administrator that the telescope is named for, allowed government discrimination against gay and lesbian employees to take place while he was in charge.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eAfter NASA finished an internal investigation this year, it \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.npr.org/2021/09/30/1041707730/shadowed-by-controversy-nasa-wont-rename-new-space-telescope?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003esaid\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e it had decided against changing the name.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBig picture:\u003c/strong\u003e There’s a lot riding on the Webb telescope. \u003ca href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/is-nasas-new-telescope-worth-the-risks/2021/12/23/d23984d0-6401-11ec-9b51-7131fa190c5e_story.html?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eOne in every three dollars\u003c/a\u003e spent on astrophysics at NASA in the last 20 years has gone to building this thing—and if something goes wrong (like, say, during its incredibly complicated \u003ca href=\"https://www.businessinsider.com/nasa-james-webb-space-telescope-to-unfold-after-launch-2021-12?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eunfolding process\u003c/a\u003e), the agency could have spent the last three decades building a multibillion-dollar pile of space debris.—\u003cem\u003eMM\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2021/12/23/us-bans-imports-from-chinas-xinjiang-region-citing-uyghur-forced-labor.html?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003enow illegal\u003c/a\u003e to import goods from China’s Xinjiang region into the US unless companies can prove they weren’t made with forced labor, according to a historic bill signed by President Biden yesterday.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe law, which Congress passed with overwhelming bipartisan support, is the US government’s biggest move yet to punish China for its reported human rights abuses and genocide against mostly Muslim minorities in the region.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBig picture: \u003c/strong\u003eWhile Xinjiang is a relatively obscure location in remote northwest China, it’s become a significant link in global supply chains, \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2021/12/23/us/politics/china-uyghurs-forced-labor.html?utm_campaign=mb\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ethe NYT writes\u003c/a\u003e. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eFactories in Xinjiang produce electronics and apparel that are shipped all over the world.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eIt also supplies an estimated 20% of the world’s cotton and nearly half of the world’s polysilicon—the raw material used to make solar panels.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBottom line: \u003c/strong\u003eUS multinationals are stumbling as they try to balance Washington’s hostile stance toward China with trying to conduct business in the world’s second-largest economy. Want one example? Intel sparked huge backlash on Chinese social media after it told its suppliers to avoid sourcing goods from Xinjiang. The company \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/intel-apologizes-after-asking-suppliers-to-avoid-chinas-xinjiang-region-11640261303?mod=hp_lead_pos4\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eapologized\u003c/a\u003e to its Chinese customers, partners, and the public class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"Amazon fulfillment center \" style=\"display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://cdn.sanity.io/images/bl383u0v/production/a949d1ad3296106255697a667a1f1326a89ce777-1024x683.jpg?w=670\u0026q=70\u0026auto=format\"\u003e\n\u003c/a\u003e\u003cspan class=\"source\" style=\"display:inline-block;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px\"\u003e\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eMatthew Horwood/Getty Images\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cdiv\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAn update to the ongoing tug-of-war between organized labor and Amazon: In \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2021/12/23/business/amazon-labor-deal.html?partner=slack\u0026smid=sl-share\" class=\"link\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ea nationwide settlement\u003c/a\u003e with the National Labor Relations Board (NLRB), the company agreed to notify past and current employees—around 1 million people—about their rights to organize.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe settlement, finalized on Wednesday, also requires Amazon to end its “15-minute rule” that required employees to only be on company property within 15 minutes of the beginning or end of their shift (making organizing a major uphill battle).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eGiven Amazon’s size—750,000+ people work in its US operations—the NLRB settlement is a massive shift in employees’ favor. And it comes amid a flurry of labor activity at Amazon in recent weeks:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThe NLRB authorized a second union election at a warehouse in Alabama after finding that the company illegally interfered in the first vote.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eAmazon warehouse workers in Staten Island refiled a request for a union vote.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eAmazon suspended its plan to ban cellphones in warehouses after six employees were killed when a tornado struck an Illinois facility. OSHA is investigating the tragedy.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eZoom out:\u003c/strong\u003e Former NLRB chair Wilma B. Liebman said the settlement sends a signal to all large employers that the agency is serious about enforcing the law.—\u003cem\u003eMK\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding-top: 12px;\"\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.facebook.com/sharer.php?u=https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/organizing-just-got-easier-at-amazon-nlrb-settlement\u0026utm_source=facebook_share\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"text-decoration: none;\" class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"\" style=\"display: inline-block;
